You are also given an annotation guide for the feature: stance.\n            Strictly follow the guide; do not invent new criteria or labels.\n\n            Your task is to classify whether it is "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant" and briefly justify your choice.\n            \n            Instructions:\n            1. Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. Provide a concise explanation for your classification using the `justification` key. Limit the justification to one sentence.\n            \n            3. label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{boc}{eight} Inflation, Employment, Economic Growth, Interest Rates, Monetary Stimulus, Exchange Rates, Commodity Prices, and Fiscal Policy Interaction.\n\n\n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item \\emph{Inflation}: A sentence pertaining to the evolution of price levels, encompassing trends of changing inflation rates or pressures on inflation. \n    \\item \\emph{Employment}: A sentence pertaining to labor market conditions, focusing on unemployment rates, job creation trends, and workforce strength. \n    \\item \\emph{Economic Growth}: A sentence pertaining to the pace and direction of economic expansion or contraction, including implications for stimulus during slowdowns or overheating during rapid growth. \n    \\item \\emph{Interest Rates}: A sentence pertaining to interest rate levels, discussing policy decisions aimed at modifying interest rates to address the needs of the economy. \n    \\item \\emph{Monetary Stimulus}: A sentence pertaining to actions that expand liquidity, such as increased asset purchases. \n    \\item \\emph{Exchange Rates}: A sentence pertaining to the movement of a nation's currency value or their economic implications. \n    \\item \\emph{Commodity Prices}: A sentence pertaining to shifts in the prices of Canada's commodities. \n    \\item \\emph{Fiscal Policy Interaction}: A sentence pertaining to the interactions between government fiscal measures (such as spending and taxation) and monetary policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: } \n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item ``Inflation is expected to exceed 3\\%, requiring tightening.''\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence implies that, due to rising inflation above the target, the Bank of Canada may adopt tightening policies to control inflationary pressures.\n    \n    \\item ``Unemployment has fallen significantly, prompting concerns about wage inflation.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This example indicates that a tight labor market may lead to wage pressures, suggesting that monetary policy could tighten to prevent an overheating economy.\n    \n    \\item ``The central bank cut rates to support the slowing economy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence states that the Bank of Canada took an accommodative stance to stimulate economic activity during economic slowdowns.\n    \n    \\item ``Weak economic activity signals the need for further monetary stimulus.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This example reflects the view that subdued growth conditions warrant more easing to boost economic performance.\n    \n    \\item ``Interest rates remained steady this month.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: This sentence portrays a situation where the policy remains unchanged, reflecting stability without leaning towards tightening or easing.\n\n    \\item ``We will take decisions one meeting at a time.'' \\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence discusses the way the Bank of Canada plans to make monetary policy decisions, however, it does not explicitly discuss any monetary policy action.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{Bank of Canada Annotation Guide} \\label{tb:boc_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Inflation} & \nBelow target or deflation concerns leading to easing. & \nAbove target or rising inflation, prompting tightening. & \nDescriptive with no policy implication. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Employment} & \nHigh unemployment, weak labor market prompting easing. & \nLow unemployment, risk of overheating, tightening bias. & \nLabor description without policy implication. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Economic Growth} & \nSlow growth or recession risk, stimulus needed. & \nStrong growth, risk of overheating. & \nGrowth data with no implied action. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Interest Rates} & \nLowering or keeping rates low to support economy. & \nRaising rates to counter inflation. & \nRate level mentioned without bias. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Monetary Stimulus} & \nIncreasing liquidity Rates} & \nDepreciation prompts easing to support growth. & \nAppreciation prompts concern about overheating. & \nNeutral exchange rate statement. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Commodity Prices} & \nFalling prices suggest weak demand, needing easing. & \nRising prices suggest inflation, tightening needed. & \nPrice movement with no policy stance. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Fiscal Policy Interaction} & \nMonetary policy needed to support lagging fiscal stimulus. & \nStrong fiscal stimulus might require tightening. & \nNeutral fiscal commentary. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: while inflation is still above central bank targets in most advanced economies, it is forecast to ease gradually.\n                "}]

label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{boc}{eight} Inflation, Employment, Economic Growth, Interest Rates, Monetary Stimulus, Exchange Rates, Commodity Prices, and Fiscal Policy Interaction.\n\n\n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item \\emph{Inflation}: A sentence pertaining to the evolution of price levels, encompassing trends of changing inflation rates or pressures on inflation. \n    \\item \\emph{Employment}: A sentence pertaining to labor market conditions, focusing on unemployment rates, job creation trends, and workforce strength. \n    \\item \\emph{Economic Growth}: A sentence pertaining to the pace and direction of economic expansion or contraction, including implications for stimulus during slowdowns or overheating during rapid growth. \n    \\item \\emph{Interest Rates}: A sentence pertaining to interest rate levels, discussing policy decisions aimed at modifying interest rates to address the needs of the economy. \n    \\item \\emph{Monetary Stimulus}: A sentence pertaining to actions that expand liquidity, such as increased asset purchases. \n    \\item \\emph{Exchange Rates}: A sentence pertaining to the movement of a nation's currency value or their economic implications. \n    \\item \\emph{Commodity Prices}: A sentence pertaining to shifts in the prices of Canada's commodities. \n    \\item \\emph{Fiscal Policy Interaction}: A sentence pertaining to the interactions between government fiscal measures (such as spending and taxation) and monetary policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: } \n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item ``Inflation is expected to exceed 3\\%, requiring tightening.''\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence implies that, due to rising inflation above the target, the Bank of Canada may adopt tightening policies to control inflationary pressures.\n    \n    \\item ``Unemployment has fallen significantly, prompting concerns about wage inflation.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This example indicates that a tight labor market may lead to wage pressures, suggesting that monetary policy could tighten to prevent an overheating economy.\n    \n    \\item ``The central bank cut rates to support the slowing economy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence states that the Bank of Canada took an accommodative stance to stimulate economic activity during economic slowdowns.\n    \n    \\item ``Weak economic activity signals the need for further monetary stimulus.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This example reflects the view that subdued growth conditions warrant more easing to boost economic performance.\n    \n    \\item ``Interest rates remained steady this month.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: This sentence portrays a situation where the policy remains unchanged, reflecting stability without leaning towards tightening or easing.\n\n    \\item ``We will take decisions one meeting at a time.'' \\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence discusses the way the Bank of Canada plans to make monetary policy decisions, however, it does not explicitly discuss any monetary policy action.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{Bank of Canada Annotation Guide} \\label{tb:boc_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Inflation} & \nBelow target or deflation concerns leading to easing. & \nAbove target or rising inflation, prompting tightening. & \nDescriptive with no policy implication. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Employment} & \nHigh unemployment, weak labor market prompting easing. & \nLow unemployment, risk of overheating, tightening bias. & \nLabor description without policy implication. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Economic Growth} & \nSlow growth or recession risk, stimulus needed. & \nStrong growth, risk of overheating. & \nGrowth data with no implied action. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Interest Rates} & \nLowering or keeping rates low to support economy. & \nRaising rates to counter inflation. & \nRate level mentioned without bias. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Monetary Stimulus} & \nIncreasing liquidity require tightening. & \nNeutral fiscal commentary. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: the three main downside risks to inflation in canada relate to sovereign debt concerns in europe, headwinds from the persistent strength of the canadian dollar, and the possibility that growth in canadian household spending could be weaker than projected.\n                "}]

pertaining to the movement of a nation's currency value or their economic implications. \n    \\item \\emph{Commodity Prices}: A sentence pertaining to shifts in the prices of Canada's commodities. \n decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: } \n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item ``Inflation is expected to exceed 3\\%, requiring tightening.''\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence implies that, due to rising inflation above the target, the Bank of Canada may adopt tightening policies to control inflationary pressures.\n    \n    \\item ``Unemployment has fallen significantly, prompting concerns about wage inflation.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This example indicates that a tight labor market may lead to wage pressures, suggesting that monetary policy could tighten to prevent an overheating economy.\n    \n    \\item ``The central bank cut rates to support the slowing economy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence states that the Bank of Canada took an accommodative stance to stimulate economic activity during economic slowdowns.\n    \n    \\item ``Weak economic activity signals the need for further monetary stimulus.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This example reflects the view that subdued growth conditions warrant more easing to boost economic performance.\n    \n    \\item ``Interest rates remained steady this month.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: This sentence portrays a situation where the policy remains unchanged, reflecting stability without leaning towards tightening or easing.\n\n    \\item ``We will take decisions one meeting at a time.'' \\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence discusses the way the Bank of Canada plans to make monetary policy decisions, however, it does not explicitly discuss any monetary policy action.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{Bank of Canada Annotation Guide} \\label{tb:boc_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Inflation} & \nBelow target or deflation concerns leading to easing. & \nAbove target or rising inflation, prompting tightening. & \nDescriptive with no policy implication. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Employment} & \nHigh unemployment, weak labor market prompting easing. & \nLow unemployment, risk of overheating, tightening bias. & \nLabor description without policy implication. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Economic Growth} & \nSlow growth or recession risk, stimulus needed. & \nStrong growth, risk of overheating. & \nGrowth data with no implied action. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Interest Rates} & \nLowering or keeping rates low to support economy. & \nRaising rates to counter inflation. & \nRate level mentioned without bias. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Monetary Stimulus} & \nIncreasing liquidity or asset purchases. & \nReducing purchases or liquidity, signaling tightening. & \nDescribes programs neutrally. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Exchange Rates} & \nDepreciation prompts easing to support growth. & \nAppreciation prompts concern about overheating. & \nNeutral exchange rate statement. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Commodity Prices} & \nFalling prices suggest weak demand, needing easing. & \nRising prices suggest inflation, tightening needed. & \nPrice movement with no policy stance. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Fiscal Policy Interaction} & \nMonetary policy needed to support lagging fiscal stimulus. & \nStrong fiscal stimulus might require tightening. & \nNeutral fiscal commentary. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: european growth has also been slightly stronger than anticipated.\n                "}]

Guide} \\label{tb:boc_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Inflation} & \nBelow target or deflation concerns leading to easing. & \nAbove target or rising inflation, prompting tightening. & \nDescriptive with no policy implication. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Employment} & \nHigh unemployment, weak labor market prompting easing. & \nLow unemployment, risk of overheating, tightening bias. & \nLabor description without policy implication. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Economic Growth} & \nSlow growth or recession risk, stimulus needed. & \nStrong growth, risk of Exchange Rates, Commodity Prices, and Fiscal Policy Interaction.\n\n\n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item \\emph{Inflation}: A sentence pertaining to the evolution of price levels, encompassing trends of changing inflation rates or pressures on inflation. \n    \\item \\emph{Employment}: A sentence pertaining to labor market conditions, focusing on unemployment rates, job creation trends, and workforce strength. \n    \\item \\emph{Economic Growth}: A sentence pertaining to the pace and direction of economic expansion or contraction, including implications for stimulus during slowdowns or overheating during rapid growth. \n    \\item \\emph{Interest Rates}: A sentence pertaining to interest rate levels, discussing policy decisions aimed at modifying interest rates to address the needs of the economy. \n    \\item \\emph{Monetary Stimulus}: A sentence pertaining to actions that expand liquidity, such as increased asset purchases. \n    \\item \\emph{Exchange Rates}: A sentence pertaining to the movement of a nation's currency value or their economic implications. \n    \\item \\emph{Commodity Prices}: A sentence pertaining to shifts in the prices of Canada's commodities. \n    \\item \\emph{Fiscal Policy Interaction}: A sentence pertaining to the interactions between government fiscal measures (such as spending and taxation) and monetary policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: } \n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item ``Inflation is expected to exceed 3\\%, requiring tightening.''\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence implies that, due to rising inflation above the target, the Bank of Canada may adopt tightening policies to control inflationary pressures.\n    \n    \\item ``Unemployment has fallen significantly, prompting concerns about wage inflation.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This example indicates that a tight labor market may lead to wage pressures, suggesting that monetary policy could tighten to prevent an overheating economy.\n    \n    \\item ``The central bank cut rates to support the slowing economy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence states that the Bank of Canada took an accommodative stance to stimulate economic activity during economic slowdowns.\n    \n    \\item ``Weak economic activity signals the need for further monetary stimulus.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This example reflects the view that subdued growth conditions warrant more easing to boost economic performance.\n    \n    \\item ``Interest rates remained steady this month.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: This sentence portrays a situation where the policy remains unchanged, reflecting stability without leaning towards tightening or easing.\n\n    \\item ``We will take decisions one meeting at a time.'' \\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence discusses the way the Bank of Canada plans to make monetary policy decisions, however, it does not explicitly discuss any monetary policy action.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{Bank of Canada Annotation or asset purchases. & \nReducing purchases or liquidity, signaling tightening. & \nDescribes programs neutrally. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Exchange Rates} & \nDepreciation prompts easing to support growth. & \nAppreciation prompts concern about overheating. & \nNeutral exchange rate statement. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Commodity Prices} & \nFalling prices suggest weak demand, needing easing. & \nRising prices suggest inflation, tightening needed. & \nPrice movement with no policy stance. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Fiscal Policy Interaction} & \nMonetary policy needed to support lagging fiscal stimulus. & \nStrong fiscal stimulus might require tightening. & \nNeutral fiscal commentary. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: the combination of increasing global excess capacity over the projection horizon and reduced commodity prices is expected to moderate global inflationary pressures.\n                "}]

"justification": "The sentence implies that decreasing commodity prices and global excess capacity will lead to moderate inflationary pressures, suggesting a dovish stance as it may warrant easier monetary policy."

label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{boc}{eight} Inflation, Employment, Economic Growth, Interest Rates, Monetary Stimulus, Exchange Rates, Commodity Prices, and Fiscal Policy Interaction.\n\n\n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item \\emph{Inflation}: A sentence pertaining to the evolution of price levels, encompassing trends of changing inflation rates or pressures on inflation. \n    \\item \\emph{Employment}: A sentence pertaining to labor market conditions, focusing on unemployment rates, job creation trends, and workforce strength. \n    \\item \\emph{Economic Growth}: A sentence pertaining to the pace and direction of economic expansion or contraction, including implications for stimulus during slowdowns or overheating during rapid growth. \n    \\item \\emph{Interest Rates}: A sentence pertaining to interest rate levels, discussing policy decisions aimed at modifying interest rates to address the needs of the economy. \n    \\item \\emph{Monetary Stimulus}: A sentence pertaining to actions that expand liquidity, such as increased asset purchases. \n    \\item \\emph{Exchange Rates}: A sentence pertaining to the movement of a nation's currency value or their economic implications. \n    \\item \\emph{Commodity Prices}: A sentence pertaining to shifts in the prices of Canada's commodities. \n    \\item \\emph{Fiscal Policy Interaction}: A sentence pertaining to the interactions between government fiscal measures (such as spending and taxation) and monetary policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: } \n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item ``Inflation is expected to exceed 3\\%, requiring tightening.''\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence implies that, due to rising inflation above the target, the Bank of Canada may adopt tightening policies to control inflationary pressures.\n    \n    \\item ``Unemployment has fallen significantly, prompting concerns about wage inflation.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This example indicates that a tight labor market may lead to wage pressures, suggesting that monetary policy could tighten to prevent an overheating economy.\n    \n    \\item ``The central bank cut rates to support the slowing economy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence states that the Bank of Canada took an accommodative stance to stimulate economic activity during economic slowdowns.\n    \n    \\item ``Weak economic activity signals the need for further monetary stimulus.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This example reflects the view that subdued growth conditions warrant more easing to boost economic performance.\n    \n    \\item ``Interest rates remained steady this month.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: This sentence portrays a situation where the policy remains unchanged, reflecting stability without leaning towards tightening or easing.\n\n    \\item ``We will take decisions one meeting at a time.'' \\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence discusses the way the Bank of Canada plans to make monetary policy decisions, however, it does not explicitly discuss any monetary policy action.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{Bank of Canada Annotation Guide} \\label{tb:boc_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Inflation} & \nBelow target or deflation concerns leading to easing. & \nAbove target or rising inflation, prompting tightening. & \nDescriptive with no policy implication. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Employment} & \nHigh unemployment, weak labor market prompting easing. & \nLow unemployment, risk of overheating, tightening bias. & \nLabor description without policy implication. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Economic Growth} & \nSlow growth or recession risk, stimulus needed. & \nStrong growth, risk of overheating. & \nGrowth data with no implied action. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Interest Rates} & \nLowering or keeping rates low to support economy. You are also given an annotation guide for the feature: stance.\n            Strictly follow the guide; do not invent new criteria or labels.\n\n            Your task is to classify whether it is "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant" and briefly justify your choice.\n            \n            Instructions:\n            1. Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. Provide a concise explanation for your classification using the `justification` key. Limit the justification to one sentence.\n            \n            3. Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{boc}{eight} Inflation, Employment, Economic Growth, Interest Rates, Monetary Stimulus, Exchange Rates, Commodity Prices, and Fiscal Policy Interaction.\n\n\n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item \\emph{Inflation}: A sentence pertaining to the evolution of price levels, encompassing trends of changing inflation rates or pressures on inflation. \n    \\item \\emph{Employment}: A sentence pertaining to labor market conditions, focusing on unemployment rates, job creation trends, and workforce strength. \n    \\item \\emph{Economic Growth}: A sentence pertaining to the pace and direction of economic expansion or contraction, including implications for stimulus during slowdowns or overheating during rapid growth. \n    \\item \\emph{Interest Rates}: A sentence pertaining to interest rate levels, discussing policy decisions aimed at modifying interest rates to address the needs of the economy. \n    \\item \\emph{Monetary Stimulus}: A sentence pertaining to actions that expand liquidity, such as increased asset purchases. \n    \\item \\emph{Exchange Rates}: A sentence pertaining to the movement of a nation's currency value or their economic implications. \n    \\item \\emph{Commodity Prices}: A sentence pertaining to shifts in the prices of Canada's commodities. \n    \\item \\emph{Fiscal Policy Interaction}: A sentence pertaining to the interactions between government fiscal measures (such as spending and taxation) and monetary policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: } \n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item ``Inflation is expected to exceed 3\\%, requiring tightening.''\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence implies that, due to rising inflation above the target, the Bank of Canada may adopt tightening policies to control inflationary pressures.\n    \n    \\item ``Unemployment has fallen significantly, prompting concerns about wage inflation.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This example indicates that a tight labor market may lead to wage pressures, suggesting that monetary policy could tighten to prevent an overheating economy.\n    \n    \\item ``The central bank cut rates to support the slowing economy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence states that the Bank of Canada took an accommodative stance to stimulate economic activity during economic slowdowns.\n    \n    \\item ``Weak economic activity signals the need for further monetary stimulus.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This example reflects the view that subdued growth conditions warrant more easing to boost economic performance.\n    \n    \\item ``Interest rates remained steady this month.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: This sentence portrays a situation where the policy remains unchanged, reflecting stability without leaning towards tightening or easing.\n\n    \\item ``We will take decisions one meeting at a time.'' \\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence discusses the way the Bank of Canada plans to make monetary policy decisions, however, it does not explicitly discuss any monetary policy action.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{Bank of Canada Annotation Guide} \\label{tb:boc_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Inflation} & \nBelow target or deflation concerns leading to easing. & \nAbove target or rising inflation, prompting tightening. & \nDescriptive with no policy implication. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Employment} & \nHigh unemployment, weak labor market prompting easing. & \nLow unemployment, risk of overheating, tightening bias. & \nLabor description without policy implication. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Economic Growth} & \nSlow growth or recession risk, stimulus needed. & \nStrong growth, risk of overheating. & \nGrowth data with no implied action. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Interest Rates} & \nLowering or keeping rates low to support economy. & \nRaising rates to counter inflation. & \nRate level mentioned without bias. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Monetary Stimulus} & \nIncreasing liquidity or asset purchases. & \nReducing purchases or liquidity, signaling tightening. & \nDescribes programs neutrally. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Exchange Rates} & \nDepreciation prompts easing to support growth. & \nAppreciation prompts concern about overheating. & \nNeutral exchange rate statement. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Commodity Prices} & \nFalling prices suggest weak demand, needing easing. & \nRising prices suggest inflation, tightening needed. & \nPrice movement with no policy stance. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Fiscal Policy Interaction} & \nMonetary policy needed to support lagging fiscal stimulus. & \nStrong fiscal stimulus might require tightening. & \nNeutral fiscal commentary. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: in canada, while global headwinds continue to restrain economic activity, domestic factors are supporting a moderate expansion.\n                "}]

"label": "neutral",
"justification": "The sentence describes the current state of the economy, mentioning both restraining and supporting factors, without implying any specific monetary policy action or bias."

changing inflation rates or pressures on inflation. \n    \\item \\emph{Employment}: A sentence pertaining to labor market conditions, focusing on unemployment rates, job creation trends, and workforce strength. \n    \\item \\emph{Economic Growth}: A sentence pertaining to the pace and direction of economic expansion or contraction, including implications for stimulus during slowdowns or overheating during rapid growth. \n    \\item \\emph{Interest Rates}: A sentence pertaining to interest rate levels, discussing policy decisions aimed at modifying interest rates to address the needs of the economy. \n    \\item \\emph{Monetary Stimulus}: A sentence pertaining to actions that expand liquidity, such as increased asset purchases. \n    \\item \\emph{Exchange Rates}: A sentence pertaining to the movement of a nation's currency value or their economic implications. \n    \\item \\emph{Commodity Prices}: A sentence pertaining to shifts in the prices of Canada's commodities. \n    \\item \\emph{Fiscal Policy Interaction}: A sentence pertaining to the interactions between government fiscal measures (such as spending and taxation) and monetary policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: } \n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item ``Inflation is expected to exceed 3\\%, requiring tightening.''\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence implies that, due to rising inflation above the target, the Bank of Canada may adopt tightening policies to control inflationary pressures.\n    \n    \\item ``Unemployment has fallen significantly, prompting concerns about wage inflation.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This example indicates that a tight labor market may lead to wage pressures, suggesting that monetary policy could tighten to prevent an overheating economy.\n    \n    \\item ``The central bank cut rates to support the slowing economy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence states that the Bank of Canada took an accommodative stance to stimulate economic activity during economic slowdowns.\n    \n    \\item ``Weak economic activity signals the need for further monetary stimulus.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This example reflects the view that subdued growth conditions warrant more easing to boost economic performance.\n    \n    \\item ``Interest rates remained steady this month.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: This sentence portrays a situation where the policy remains unchanged, reflecting stability without leaning towards tightening or easing.\n\n    \\item ``We will take decisions one meeting at a time.'' \\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence discusses the way the Bank of Canada plans to make monetary policy decisions, however, it does not explicitly discuss any monetary policy action.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{Bank of Canada Annotation Guide} \\label{tb:boc_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Inflation} & \nBelow target or deflation concerns leading to easing. & \nAbove target or rising inflation, prompting tightening. & \nDescriptive with no policy implication. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Employment} & \nHigh unemployment, weak labor market prompting easing. & \nLow unemployment, risk of overheating, tightening bias. & \nLabor description without policy implication. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Economic Growth} & \nSlow growth or recession risk, stimulus needed. & \nStrong growth, risk of overheating. & \nGrowth data with no implied action. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Interest Rates} & \nLowering or keeping rates low to support economy. & \nRaising rates to counter inflation. & \nRate level mentioned without bias. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Monetary Stimulus} & \nIncreasing liquidity or asset purchases. & \nReducing purchases or liquidity, signaling tightening. & \nDescribes programs neutrally. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Exchange Rates} & \nDepreciation prompts easing to support growth. & \nAppreciation prompts concern about overheating. & \nNeutral exchange rate statement. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Commodity Prices} & \nFalling prices suggest weak demand, needing easing. & \nRising prices suggest inflation, tightening needed. & \nPrice movement with no policy stance. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Fiscal Policy Interaction} & \nMonetary policy needed to support lagging fiscal stimulus. & \nStrong fiscal stimulus might require tightening. & \nNeutral fiscal commentary. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: in this context, the forecast for the global economy has been marked down slightly from the banks april monetary policy report (mpr).\n                "}]

"label": "dovish",
"justification": "The sentence implies a slight downgrade in the global economy's forecast, which may warrant a more accommodative monetary policy stance to support economic growth."

sentence portrays a situation where the policy remains unchanged, reflecting stability without leaning towards tightening or easing.\n\n    \\item ``We will take decisions one meeting at a time.'' \\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence discusses the way the Bank of Canada plans to make monetary policy decisions, however, it does not explicitly discuss any monetary policy action.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{Bank of Canada Annotation \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Inflation} & \nBelow target or deflation concerns leading to easing. & \nAbove target or rising inflation, prompting tightening. & \nDescriptive with no policy implication. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Employment} & \nHigh unemployment, weak labor market prompting easing. & \nLow unemployment, risk of overheating, tightening bias. & \nLabor description without Exchange Rates, Commodity Prices, and Fiscal Policy Interaction.\n\n\n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item \\emph{Inflation}: A sentence pertaining to the evolution of price levels, encompassing trends of changing inflation rates or pressures on inflation. \n    \\item \\emph{Employment}: A sentence pertaining to labor market conditions, focusing on unemployment rates, job creation trends, and workforce strength. \n    \\item \\emph{Economic Growth}: A sentence pertaining to the pace and direction of economic expansion or contraction, including implications for stimulus during slowdowns or overheating during rapid growth. \n    \\item \\emph{Interest Rates}: A sentence pertaining to interest rate levels, discussing policy decisions aimed at modifying interest rates to address the needs of the economy. \n    \\item \\emph{Monetary Stimulus}: A sentence pertaining to actions that expand liquidity, such as increased asset purchases. \n    \\item \\emph{Exchange Rates}: A sentence pertaining to the movement of a nation's currency value or their economic implications. \n    \\item \\emph{Commodity Prices}: A sentence pertaining to shifts in the prices of Canada's commodities. \n    \\item \\emph{Fiscal Policy Interaction}: A sentence pertaining to the interactions between government fiscal measures (such as spending and taxation) and monetary policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: } \n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item ``Inflation is expected to exceed 3\\%, requiring tightening.''\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence implies that, due to rising inflation above the target, the Bank of Canada may adopt tightening policies to control inflationary pressures.\n    \n    \\item ``Unemployment has fallen significantly, prompting concerns about wage inflation.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This example indicates that a tight labor market may lead to wage pressures, suggesting that monetary policy could tighten to prevent an overheating economy.\n    \n    \\item ``The central bank cut rates to support the slowing economy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence states that the Bank of Canada took an accommodative stance to stimulate economic activity during economic slowdowns.\n    \n    \\item ``Weak economic activity signals the need for further monetary stimulus.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This example You are also given an annotation guide for the feature: stance.\n            Strictly follow the guide; do not invent new criteria or labels.\n\n            Your task is to classify whether it is "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant" and briefly justify your choice.\n            \n            Instructions:\n            1. label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{boc}{eight} Inflation, Employment, Economic Growth, Interest Rates, Monetary Stimulus, Exchange Rates, Commodity Prices, and Fiscal Policy Interaction.\n\n\n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item \\emph{Inflation}: A sentence pertaining to the evolution of price levels, encompassing trends of changing inflation rates or pressures on inflation. \n    \\item \\emph{Employment}: A sentence pertaining to labor market conditions, focusing on unemployment rates, job creation trends, and workforce strength. \n    \\item \\emph{Economic Growth}: A sentence pertaining to the pace and direction of economic expansion or contraction, including implications for stimulus during slowdowns or overheating during rapid growth. \n    \\item \\emph{Interest Rates}: A sentence pertaining to interest rate levels, discussing policy decisions aimed at modifying interest rates to address the needs of the economy. \n    \\item \\emph{Monetary Stimulus}: A sentence pertaining to actions that expand liquidity, such as increased asset purchases. \n    \\item \\emph{Exchange Rates}: A sentence pertaining to the movement of a nation's currency value or their economic implications. \n    \\item \\emph{Commodity Prices}: A sentence pertaining to shifts in the prices of Canada's commodities. \n    \\item \\emph{Fiscal Policy Interaction}: A sentence pertaining to the interactions between government fiscal measures (such as spending and taxation) and monetary policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: } \n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item ``Inflation is expected to exceed 3\\%, requiring tightening.''\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence implies that, due to rising inflation above the target, the Bank of Canada may adopt tightening policies to control inflationary pressures.\n    \n    \\item ``Unemployment has fallen significantly, prompting concerns about wage inflation.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This example indicates that a tight labor market may lead to wage pressures, suggesting that monetary policy could tighten to prevent an overheating economy.\n    \n    \\item ``The central bank cut rates to support the slowing economy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence states that the Bank of Canada took an accommodative stance to stimulate economic activity during economic slowdowns.\n    \n    \\item ``Weak economic activity signals the need for further monetary stimulus.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This example reflects the view that subdued growth conditions warrant more easing to boost economic performance.\n    \n    \\item ``Interest rates remained steady this month.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: This sentence portrays a situation where the policy remains unchanged, reflecting stability without leaning towards tightening or easing.\n\n    \\item ``We will take decisions one meeting at a time.'' \\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence discusses the way the Bank of Canada plans to make monetary policy decisions, however, it does not explicitly discuss any monetary policy action.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{Bank of Canada Annotation \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Inflation} & inflation reflects persistent material excess capacity, heightened competitive pressures on retailers, relatively subdued wage increases, and some temporary sector-specific factors.\n                "}]

"label": "dovish",
"justification": "The sentence highlights various factors contributing to weak core inflation, implying that the economy may need accommodative monetary policies to support growth."
}

Exchange Rates, Commodity Prices, and Fiscal Policy Interaction.\n\n\n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item \\emph{Inflation}: A sentence pertaining to the evolution of price levels, encompassing trends of changing inflation rates or pressures on inflation. \n    \\item \\emph{Employment}: A sentence pertaining to labor market conditions, focusing on unemployment rates, job creation trends, and workforce strength. \n    \\item \\emph{Economic Growth}: A sentence pertaining to the pace and direction of economic expansion or contraction, including implications for stimulus during slowdowns or overheating during rapid growth. \n    \\item \\emph{Interest Rates}: A sentence pertaining to interest rate levels, discussing policy decisions aimed at modifying interest rates to address the needs of the economy. \n    \\item \\emph{Monetary Stimulus}: A sentence pertaining to actions that expand liquidity, such as increased asset purchases. \n    \\item \\emph{Exchange Rates}: A sentence pertaining to the movement of a nation's currency value or their economic implications. \n    \\item \\emph{Commodity Prices}: A sentence pertaining to shifts in the prices of Canada's commodities. \n    \\item \\emph{Fiscal Policy Interaction}: A sentence pertaining to the interactions between government fiscal measures (such as spending and taxation) and monetary policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: } \n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item ``Inflation is expected to exceed 3\\%, requiring tightening.''\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence implies that, due to rising inflation above the target, the Bank of Canada may adopt tightening policies to control inflationary pressures.\n    \n    \\item ``Unemployment has fallen significantly, prompting concerns about wage inflation.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This example indicates that a tight labor market may lead to wage pressures, suggesting that monetary policy could tighten to prevent an overheating economy.\n    \n    \\item ``The central bank cut rates to support the slowing economy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence states that the Bank of Canada took an accommodative stance to stimulate economic activity during economic slowdowns.\n    \n    \\item ``Weak economic activity signals the need for further monetary stimulus.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This example reflects the view that subdued growth conditions warrant more easing to boost economic performance.\n    \n    \\item ``Interest rates remained steady this month.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: This sentence portrays a situation where the policy remains unchanged, reflecting stability without leaning towards tightening or easing.\n\n    \\item ``We will take decisions one meeting at a time.'' \\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence discusses the way the Bank of Canada plans to make monetary policy decisions, however, it does not explicitly discuss any monetary policy action.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{Bank of Canada Annotation Guide} \\label{tb:boc_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Inflation} & \nBelow target or deflation concerns leading to easing. & \nAbove target or rising inflation, prompting tightening. & \nDescriptive with no policy implication. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Employment} & \nHigh unemployment, weak labor market prompting easing. & \nLow unemployment, risk of overheating, tightening bias. & \nLabor description without policy implication. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Economic Growth} & \nSlow growth or recession risk, stimulus needed. & \nStrong growth, risk of overheating. & \nGrowth data with no implied action. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Interest Rates} & \nLowering or keeping rates low to support economy. & \nRaising rates to counter inflation. & \nRate level mentioned without bias. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Monetary Stimulus} & \nIncreasing liquidity or asset purchases. & \nReducing purchases or liquidity, signaling tightening. & \nDescribes programs neutrally. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Exchange Rates} & \nDepreciation prompts easing to support growth. & \nAppreciation prompts concern about overheating. & \nNeutral exchange rate statement. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. require tightening. & \nNeutral fiscal commentary. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: the banks core measures of Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{boc}{eight} Inflation, Employment, Economic Growth, Interest Rates, Monetary Stimulus, Exchange Rates, Commodity Prices, and Fiscal Policy Interaction.\n\n\n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item \\emph{Inflation}: A sentence pertaining to the evolution of price levels, encompassing trends of changing inflation rates or pressures on inflation. \n    \\item \\emph{Employment}: A sentence pertaining to labor market conditions, focusing on unemployment rates, job creation trends, and workforce strength. \n    \\item \\emph{Economic Growth}: A sentence pertaining to the pace and direction of economic expansion or contraction, including implications for stimulus during slowdowns or overheating during rapid growth. \n    \\item \\emph{Interest Rates}: A sentence pertaining to interest rate levels, discussing policy decisions aimed at modifying interest rates to address the needs of the economy. \n    \\item \\emph{Monetary Stimulus}: A sentence pertaining to actions that expand liquidity, such as increased asset purchases. \n    \\item \\emph{Exchange Rates}: A sentence pertaining to the movement of a nation's currency value or their economic implications. \n    \\item \\emph{Commodity Prices}: A sentence pertaining to shifts in the prices of Canada's commodities. \n    \\item \\emph{Fiscal Policy Interaction}: A sentence pertaining to the interactions between government fiscal measures (such as spending and taxation) and monetary policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: } \n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item ``Inflation is expected to exceed 3\\%, requiring tightening.''\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence implies that, due to rising inflation above the target, the Bank of Canada may adopt tightening policies to control inflationary pressures.\n    \n    \\item ``Unemployment has fallen significantly, prompting concerns about wage inflation.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This example indicates that a tight labor market may lead to wage pressures, suggesting that monetary policy could tighten to prevent an overheating economy.\n    \n    \\item ``The central bank cut rates to support the slowing economy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence states that the Bank of Canada took an accommodative stance to stimulate economic activity during economic slowdowns.\n    \n    \\item ``Weak economic activity signals the need for further monetary stimulus.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This example reflects the view that subdued growth conditions warrant more easing to boost economic performance.\n    \n    \\item ``Interest rates remained steady this month.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: This sentence portrays a situation where the policy remains unchanged, reflecting stability without leaning towards tightening or easing.\n\n    \\item ``We will take decisions one meeting at a time.'' \\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence discusses the way the Bank of Canada plans to make monetary policy decisions, however, it does not explicitly discuss any monetary policy action.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{Bank of Canada Annotation Guide} \\label{tb:boc_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Inflation} & \nBelow target or deflation concerns leading to easing. & \nAbove target or rising inflation, prompting tightening. & \nDescriptive with no policy implication. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Employment} & \nHigh unemployment, weak labor market prompting easing. & \nLow unemployment, risk of overheating, tightening bias. & \nLabor description without policy implication. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Economic Growth} & \nSlow growth or recession risk, stimulus needed. & \nStrong growth, risk of overheating. & \nGrowth data with no implied action. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Interest Rates} & \nLowering or keeping rates low to support economy. & \nRaising rates to counter inflation. & \nRate level mentioned without bias. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Monetary Stimulus} & \nIncreasing liquidity or asset purchases. & \nReducing purchases or liquidity, signaling tightening. & \nDescribes programs neutrally. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Exchange Rates} & \nDepreciation prompts easing to support growth. & \nAppreciation prompts concern about overheating. & \nNeutral exchange rate statement. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Commodity Prices} & \nFalling prices suggest weak demand, needing easing. & \nRising prices suggest inflation, tightening needed. & \nPrice movement with no policy stance. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Fiscal Policy Interaction} & \nMonetary policy needed to support lagging fiscal stimulus. & \nStrong fiscal stimulus might require tightening. & \nNeutral fiscal commentary. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: economic activity in emerging-market economies is expected to moderate to a still-robust pace over the projection horizon, supported by an easing of macroeconomic policies.\n                "}]

pertaining to the movement of a nation's currency value or their economic implications. \n    \\item \\emph{Commodity Prices}: A sentence pertaining to shifts in the prices of Canada's commodities. \n    \\item \\emph{Fiscal Policy Interaction}: A sentence pertaining to the interactions between government fiscal measures (such as spending and taxation) and monetary policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: } \n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item ``Inflation is expected to exceed 3\\%, requiring tightening.''\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence implies that, due to rising inflation above the target, the Bank of Canada may adopt tightening policies to control inflationary pressures.\n    \n    \\item ``Unemployment has fallen significantly, prompting concerns about wage inflation.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This example indicates that a tight labor market may lead to wage pressures, suggesting that monetary policy could tighten to prevent an overheating economy.\n    \n    \\item ``The central bank cut rates to support the slowing economy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence states that the Bank of Canada took an accommodative stance to stimulate economic activity during economic slowdowns.\n    \n    \\item ``Weak economic activity signals the need for further monetary stimulus.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This example reflects the view that subdued growth conditions warrant more easing to boost economic performance.\n    \n    \\item ``Interest rates remained steady this month.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: This sentence portrays a situation where the policy remains unchanged, reflecting stability without leaning towards tightening or easing.\n\n    \\item ``We will take decisions one meeting at a time.'' \\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence discusses the way the Bank of Canada plans to make monetary policy decisions, however, it does not explicitly discuss any monetary policy action.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{Bank of Canada Annotation Guide} \\label{tb:boc_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Inflation} & \nBelow target or deflation concerns leading to easing. & \nAbove target or rising inflation, prompting tightening. & \nDescriptive with no policy implication. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Employment} & \nHigh unemployment, weak labor market prompting easing. & \nLow unemployment, risk of overheating, tightening bias. & \nLabor description without policy implication. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Economic Growth} & \nSlow growth or recession risk, stimulus needed. & \nStrong growth, risk of overheating. & \nGrowth data with no implied action. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Interest Rates} & \nLowering or keeping rates low to support economy. & \nRaising rates to counter inflation. & \nRate level mentioned without bias. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Monetary Stimulus} & \nIncreasing liquidity or asset purchases. & \nReducing purchases or liquidity, signaling tightening. & \nDescribes programs neutrally. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Exchange Rates} & \nDepreciation prompts easing to support growth. & \nAppreciation prompts concern about overheating. & \nNeutral exchange rate statement. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Commodity Prices} & \nFalling prices suggest weak demand, needing easing. & \nRising prices suggest inflation, tightening needed. & \nPrice movement with no policy stance. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Fiscal Policy Interaction} & \nMonetary policy needed to support lagging fiscal stimulus. & \nStrong fiscal stimulus might require tightening. & \nNeutral fiscal commentary. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: at the same time, economies continue to adjust to lower oil prices, which have fluctuated at or below levels assumed in the january mpr.\n                "}]

action.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{Bank of Canada Annotation Exchange Rates, Commodity Prices, and Fiscal Policy Interaction.\n\n\n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item \\emph{Inflation}: A sentence pertaining to the evolution of price levels, encompassing trends of changing inflation rates or pressures on inflation. \n    \\item \\emph{Employment}: A sentence pertaining to labor market conditions, focusing on unemployment rates, job creation trends, and workforce strength. \n    \\item \\emph{Economic Growth}: A sentence pertaining to the pace and direction of economic expansion or contraction, including implications for stimulus during slowdowns or overheating during rapid growth. \n    \\item \\emph{Interest Rates}: A sentence pertaining to interest rate levels, discussing policy decisions aimed at modifying interest rates to address the needs of the economy. \n    \\item \\emph{Monetary Stimulus}: A sentence pertaining to actions that expand liquidity, such as increased asset purchases. \n    \\item \\emph{Exchange Rates}: A sentence pertaining to the movement of a nation's currency value or their economic implications. \n    \\item \\emph{Commodity Prices}: A sentence pertaining to shifts in the prices of Canada's commodities. \n    \\item \\emph{Fiscal Policy Interaction}: A sentence pertaining to the interactions between government fiscal measures (such as spending and taxation) and monetary policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: } \n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item ``Inflation is expected to exceed 3\\%, requiring tightening.''\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence implies that, due to rising inflation above the target, the Bank of Canada may adopt tightening policies to control inflationary pressures.\n    \n    \\item ``Unemployment has fallen significantly, prompting concerns about wage inflation.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This example indicates that a tight labor market may lead to wage pressures, suggesting that monetary policy could tighten to prevent an overheating economy.\n    \n    \\item ``The central bank cut rates to support the slowing economy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence states that the Bank of Canada took an accommodative stance to stimulate economic activity during economic slowdowns.\n    \n    \\item ``Weak economic activity signals the need for further monetary stimulus.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This example reflects the view that subdued growth conditions warrant more easing to boost economic performance.\n    \n    \\item ``Interest rates remained steady this month.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: This sentence portrays a situation where the policy remains unchanged, reflecting stability without leaning towards tightening or easing.\n\n    \\item ``We will take decisions one meeting at a time.'' Exchange Rates, Commodity Prices, and Fiscal Policy Interaction.\n\n\n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item \\emph{Inflation}: A sentence pertaining to the evolution of price levels, encompassing trends of changing inflation rates or pressures on inflation. \n    \\item \\emph{Employment}: A sentence pertaining to labor market conditions, focusing on unemployment rates, job creation trends, and workforce strength. \n    \\item \\emph{Economic Growth}: A sentence pertaining to the pace and direction of economic expansion or contraction, including implications for stimulus during slowdowns or overheating during rapid growth. \n    \\item \\emph{Interest Rates}: A sentence pertaining to interest rate levels, discussing policy decisions aimed at modifying interest rates to address the needs of the economy. \n    \\item \\emph{Monetary Stimulus}: A sentence pertaining to actions that expand liquidity, such as increased asset purchases. \n    \\item \\emph{Exchange Rates}: A sentence pertaining to the movement of a nation's currency value or their economic implications. \n    \\item \\emph{Commodity Prices}: A sentence pertaining to shifts in the prices of Canada's commodities. \n    \\item \\emph{Fiscal Policy Interaction}: A sentence pertaining to the interactions between government fiscal measures (such as spending and taxation) and monetary policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: } \n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item ``Inflation is expected to exceed 3\\%, requiring tightening.''\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence implies that, due to rising inflation above the target, the Bank of Canada may adopt tightening policies to control inflationary pressures.\n    \n    \\item ``Unemployment has fallen significantly, prompting concerns about wage inflation.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This example indicates that a tight labor market may lead to wage pressures, suggesting that monetary policy could tighten to prevent an overheating economy.\n    \n    \\item ``The central bank cut rates to support the slowing economy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence states that the Bank of Canada took an accommodative stance to stimulate economic activity during economic slowdowns.\n    \n    \\item ``Weak economic activity signals the need for further monetary stimulus.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This example reflects the view that subdued growth conditions warrant more easing to boost economic performance.\n    \n    \\item ``Interest rates remained steady this month.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: This sentence portrays a situation where the policy remains unchanged, reflecting stability without leaning towards tightening or easing.\n\n    \\item ``We will take decisions one meeting at a time.'' \\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence discusses the way the Bank of Canada plans to make monetary policy decisions, however, it does not explicitly discuss any monetary policy action.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{Bank of Canada Annotation \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Inflation} & label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{boc}{eight} Inflation, Employment, Economic Growth, Interest Rates, Monetary Stimulus, Exchange Rates, Commodity Prices, and Fiscal Policy Interaction.\n\n\n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item \\emph{Inflation}: A sentence pertaining to the evolution of price levels, encompassing trends of changing inflation rates or pressures on inflation. \n    \\item \\emph{Employment}: A sentence pertaining to labor market conditions, focusing on unemployment rates, job creation trends, and workforce strength. \n    \\item \\emph{Economic Growth}: A sentence pertaining to the pace and direction of economic expansion or contraction, including implications for stimulus during slowdowns or overheating during rapid growth. \n    \\item \\emph{Interest Rates}: A sentence pertaining to interest rate levels, discussing policy decisions aimed at modifying interest rates to address the needs of the economy. \n    \\item \\emph{Monetary Stimulus}: A sentence pertaining to actions that expand liquidity, such as increased asset purchases. \n    \\item \\emph{Exchange Rates}: A sentence pertaining to the movement of a nation's currency value or their economic implications. \n    \\item \\emph{Commodity Prices}: A sentence pertaining to shifts in the prices of Canada's commodities. \n    \\item \\emph{Fiscal Policy Interaction}: A sentence pertaining to the interactions between government fiscal measures (such as spending and taxation) and monetary policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: } \n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item ``Inflation is expected to exceed 3\\%, requiring tightening.''\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence implies that, due to rising inflation above the target, the Bank of Canada may adopt tightening policies to control inflationary pressures.\n    \n    \\item ``Unemployment has fallen significantly, prompting concerns about wage inflation.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This example indicates that a tight labor market may lead to wage pressures, suggesting that monetary policy could tighten to prevent an overheating economy.\n    \n    \\item ``The central bank cut rates to support the slowing economy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence states that the Bank of Canada took an accommodative stance to stimulate economic activity during economic slowdowns.\n    \n    \\item ``Weak economic activity signals the need for further monetary stimulus.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This example reflects the view that subdued growth conditions warrant more easing to boost economic performance.\n    \n    \\item ``Interest rates remained steady this month.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: This sentence portrays a situation where the policy remains unchanged, reflecting stability without leaning towards tightening or easing.\n\n    \\item ``We will take decisions one meeting at a time.'' \\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence discusses the way the Bank of Canada plans to make monetary policy decisions, however, it does not explicitly discuss any monetary policy action.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{Bank of Canada Annotation Guide} \\label{tb:boc_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Inflation} & \nBelow target or deflation concerns leading to easing. & \nAbove target or rising inflation, prompting tightening. & \nDescriptive with no policy implication. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Employment} & \nHigh unemployment, weak labor market prompting easing. & \nLow unemployment, risk of overheating, tightening bias. & \nLabor description without policy implication. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Economic Growth} & \nSlow growth or recession risk, stimulus needed. & \nStrong growth, risk of overheating. & \nGrowth data with no implied action. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Interest Rates} & \nLowering or keeping rates low to support economy. & \nRaising rates to counter inflation. & \nRate level mentioned without bias. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Monetary Stimulus} & \nIncreasing liquidity or asset purchases. & \nReducing purchases or liquidity, signaling tightening. & \nDescribes programs neutrally. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Exchange Rates} & \nDepreciation prompts easing to support growth. & \nAppreciation prompts concern about overheating. & \nNeutral exchange rate statement. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Commodity Prices} & \nFalling prices suggest weak demand, needing easing. & \nRising prices suggest inflation, tightening needed. & \nPrice movement with no policy stance. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Fiscal Policy Interaction} & \nMonetary policy needed to support lagging fiscal stimulus. & \nStrong fiscal stimulus might require tightening. & \nNeutral fiscal commentary. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: further excess demand has built up in the canadian economy.\n                "}]

changing inflation rates or pressures on inflation. \n    \\item \\emph{Employment}: A sentence pertaining to labor market conditions, focusing on unemployment rates, job creation trends, and workforce strength. \n    \\item \\emph{Economic Growth}: A sentence pertaining to the pace and direction of economic expansion or contraction, including implications for stimulus during slowdowns or overheating during rapid growth. \n    \\item \\emph{Interest Rates}: A sentence pertaining to interest rate levels, discussing policy decisions aimed at modifying interest rates to address the needs of the economy. \n    \\item \\emph{Monetary Stimulus}: A sentence pertaining to actions that expand liquidity, such as increased asset purchases. \n    \\item \\emph{Exchange Rates}: A sentence pertaining to the movement of a nation's currency value or their economic implications. \n    \\item \\emph{Commodity Prices}: A sentence pertaining to shifts in the prices of Canada's commodities. \n    \\item \\emph{Fiscal Policy Interaction}: A sentence pertaining to the interactions between government fiscal measures (such as spending and taxation) and monetary policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: } \n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item ``Inflation is expected to exceed 3\\%, requiring tightening.''\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence implies that, due to rising inflation above the target, the Bank of Canada may adopt tightening policies to control inflationary pressures.\n    \n    \\item ``Unemployment has fallen significantly, prompting concerns about wage inflation.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This example indicates that a tight labor market may lead to wage pressures, suggesting that monetary policy could tighten to prevent an overheating economy.\n    \n    \\item ``The central bank cut rates to support the slowing economy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence states that the Bank of Canada took an accommodative stance to stimulate economic activity during economic slowdowns.\n    \n    \\item ``Weak economic activity signals the need for further monetary stimulus.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This example reflects the view that subdued growth conditions warrant more easing to boost economic performance.\n    \n    \\item ``Interest rates remained steady this month.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: This sentence portrays a situation where the policy remains unchanged, reflecting stability without leaning towards tightening or easing.\n\n    \\item ``We will take decisions one meeting at a time.'' \\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence discusses the way the Bank of Canada plans to make monetary policy decisions, however, it does not explicitly discuss any monetary policy action.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{Bank of Canada Annotation Guide} \\label{tb:boc_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Inflation} & \nBelow target or deflation concerns leading to easing. & \nAbove target or rising inflation, prompting tightening. & \nDescriptive with no policy implication. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Employment} & \nHigh unemployment, weak labor market prompting easing. & \nLow unemployment, risk of overheating, tightening bias. & \nLabor description without policy implication. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Economic Growth} & \nSlow growth or recession risk, stimulus needed. & \nStrong growth, risk of overheating. & \nGrowth data with no implied action. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Interest Rates} & \nLowering or keeping rates low to support economy. & \nRaising rates to counter inflation. & \nRate level mentioned without bias. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Monetary Stimulus} & \nIncreasing liquidity or asset purchases. & \nReducing purchases or liquidity, signaling tightening. & \nDescribes programs neutrally. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Exchange Rates} & \nDepreciation prompts easing to support growth. & \nAppreciation prompts concern about overheating. & \nNeutral exchange rate statement. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Commodity Prices} & \nFalling prices suggest weak demand, needing easing. & \nRising prices suggest inflation, tightening needed. & \nPrice movement with no policy stance. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Fiscal Policy Interaction} & \nMonetary policy needed to support lagging fiscal stimulus. & \nStrong fiscal stimulus might require tightening. & \nNeutral fiscal commentary. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: the bank acknowledges recent softness in inflation but judges this to be temporary.\n                "}]

"label": "neutral",
"justification": "The sentence acknowledges recent softness in inflation but judges it to be temporary, implying no immediate policy action is needed, hence a neutral stance."
}
